did.unittitle: Clifford Drury and William Pugh collection on World War II

bioghist.p: Clifford M Drury (1897-1894) was an historian and bibliographer of Presbyterian history and history of the Protestant missions of the Pacific Northwest. He was born in Iowa and received his B.D. from San Francisco Theological Seminary in 1922 and Ph.D. from the University of Edinburgh in 1932. He was pastor of churches in California, Shanghai, and Idaho, and a professor of church history at San Francisco Theological Seminary, 1938-1963. From 1944-1956 he was the official historian of the U.S. Navy, Chaplain Corps. The Rev. Dr. William Barrow Pugh (1889-1950) was a Stated Clerk of the Northern Presbyterians' General Assembly. He was awarded the U.S. Medal for Merit for his wartime services as chairman of the General Commission on Army and Navy Chaplains.

scopecontent.p: This is an artificial collection compiled by Drury and Pugh which contains publications by the PCUSA on services during World War II, as well as non-Presbyterian material. Materials related to chaplains serving in World War II include: publicity photographs of chaplains in the army and navy; training manuals; and press clippings on Pugh. Materials related to social issues during wartime include: pamphlets on refugees and POWs, housing, food and rationing, and returning service personnel; pamphlets published by the Presbyterian Committee on Camp and Church Activities; newsletters, including The World Over, The Vital Speeches, Spiritual Issues and the War, and The Reporter (later called The Reporter for Conscience's Sake); speeches; press releases from Church World Service and other Presbyterian organizations; reports from the Washington Council of Churches and Christian Education; and WCC reports on wartime activities. There are also pamphlets and news clippings on relief work in the Pacific Islands; war posters; published volumes; a small collection of wartime publicity materials from Standard Oil, photographs from a celebration of the 150th anniversary of the Mare Island Naval Shipyard, and several magazines.
